title: Vanstone: Rider Nation turns blasé over hapless Roughriders | Video
text:
he season that resulted in yet another loss. 
The Saskatchewan Roughriders simply cannot wrap up a season - or a ball-carrier. 
Sixteen games into the Roughriders' seemingly interminable 2015 campaign, the mistakes that plagued the Green and White in Week 1 are still being made. 
Has anyone learned to make a tackle? 
Hasn't everyone seen enough? 
A significant portion of the Rider Nation has tuned out, judging by the abundance of empty seats at Mosaic Stadium on Saturday - when the Roughriders gassed a 21-3 lead and bowed 35-24 to the Edmonton Eskimos. The latest loss left Saskatchewan with a 2-14 record for the first time since 1980. 
The announced paid attendance was 30,488. But how many people were actually in the gallery for the 10th-last regular-season game at Mosaic Stadium 1.0? 
Were there even 20,000 people at the game? 
And how many people would have shown up if the Roughriders/Eskimos matchup had coincided with a seventh game in the Toronto Blue Jays/Kansas City Royals series? 
Driving up to the stadium, traffic flowed without interruption or irritation 45 minutes before the game. There was an eerie silence as an antiquated scribe waddled toward the old Taylor Field. 
Members of the Riders Pep Band did their utmost to drum up some enthusiasm, but it seemed that many blank-faced attendees approached the gates in the same fashion that they would line up for an inoculation. 
The Roughriders did take some shots downfield once the proceedings began - exploding for three early touchdowns against an Eskimos team that is noted for its carnivorous defence - only to unravel yet again. 
Edmonton rang up 32 successive points, aided by an alleged Saskatchewan defence that treated the Rider Nation to innovative ways to miss, or not even attempt, a tackle. 
There was Roughriders defensive back Junior Mertile, for example, standing idly by as Adarius Bowman shook off Tyree Hollins - who was attempting to strip the ball from the Eskimos receiver - and merrily waltzed into the end zone. 
While witnessing yet another festival of missed tackles, it was hard not to miss the good old days - which weren't even two years ago, actually. On Nov. 24, 2013, quarterback Darian Durant held the Grey Cup over his head as the Roughriders celebrated the first home-field championship-game victory in franchise history. 
Now the Roughriders are in over their heads against most opponents. 
It doesn't help matters that Durant is recovering from his second consecutive season-ending injury - having suffered a ruptured left Achilles tendon in the opener against the Winnipeg Blue Bombers. 
In that game, as in Saturday's contest, some quick strikes on offence were not enough to prevent the foe from prevailing. Ultimately, matador defence was the Riders' undoing. Again. 
As if by script, the same old problems became painfully evident - much like several thousand vacant seats. 
Was the stadium, or the figurative glass, half-empty or half-full? 
There were a few encouraging signs. The young quarterbacks, Brett Smith and Keith Price, performed reasonably well. So did receivers Ryan Smith and Naaman Roosevelt, who should be two key components of a desperately needed rebuilding initiative. Keenan Mac-Dougall was impressive, and aggressive, in his introductory start at safety. 
But then, of course, there was the regularly scheduled collapse ... and another loss to a divisional rival ... and the widespread indifference toward a late-October game. 
Not so long ago, those games meant something. A chill in the air signalled that the Roughriders' season was reaching a culmination. There was a buzz around the imminent playoffs and an insatiable appetite for all things green and white. 
As a pronounced and disillusioning contrast, there are non-events such as Saturday's game. 
Even before the final gun sounded, the brave souls who did show up for a glorified exhibition contest silently shuffled out of the stadium. 
All hope had disappeared much earlier - in August, come to think of it. 
And two games remain in the season that never ends.
